text:
There is a problem in tomcat rc1 when parsing a jsp-file. If there were some 
<jsp:include> statesment - the <jsp:param> statement doesn't work well.

Example:

<jsp:include page="/servlet/testServlet" flush="true">
<jsp:param name="Test" value="height=20, width=20"/>
</jsp:include>

when I now parse the params (request-object) in the servlet testServlet, i 
couldn't find a param "Test". The Problem is the "=" Char in the value field. 
Also Tomcat has its problems with ";", "&" or linebreaks in the value-clause of 
the jsp:param statement. Therefore we cannot use tomcat4 to build our 
webapplication. Tomcat 3.x works fine with "=" Chars, but still has its problem 
with "&", ";" or linebreaks. 

Sincerely

  Ronald Bernhard Interflex GmbH & CoKG
creator: rbernhar@interflex.de

text:
Servlet containers require that the URLs they process must conform to spec
requirements.  In this case, the relevant spec is RFC 2396, Section 3.4, which
states that characters like '=' and '&' are reserved.  That means a URL from a
client would need to URL encode a parameter value that includes them (like the
one you are trying to use).

The same rules apply to query parameters specified with <jsp:include> or
RequestDispatcher.include().
